text: Research Abstract: This is a research titled: "Evidences of Success for the Most Correct Method of the Compilation of Al-Siddiq". It refers to the second compilation of the Holy Quran, which was undertaken, executed, and overseen by the Rightly Guided Caliph Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq upon the counsel of Al-Farooq Umar bin Al-Khattab, assigning the task of heading the compilation committee to Zaid bin Thabit Al-Ansari. The compilation was also carried out with the participation of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, and this took place in the year 12 AH. Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, rose to the task and collected the Quran between the two covers of a single volume after it had been scattered during the first Prophetic compilation era. This occurred following the killing of seventy Quran reciters in the Battle of Yamama, which raised fears that the Quran might be lost with the loss of its carriers. The researcher has compiled this research and desired to present it in a concise form that combines academic grounding with verification and scrutiny, especially regarding certain issues where disagreement occurred among some scholars, and some issues and cases that have been frequently discussed and circulated without verification until they became taken for granted. The researcher also took care to ensure smooth style, ease of expression, eloquence of wording, and good presentation, to bring it closer to the view of its seekers, making it accessible and easy to handle for those interested, hoping that Allah accepts it from His weak servant with a good acceptance and causes it to grow.

text: Introduction: Praise be to Allah, and blessings and peace be upon the Messenger of Allah, his family, his companions, and those who follow him. To proceed: The Holy Quran is the speech of the Lord of the Worlds and His clear revelation, which Allah sent down upon the Seal of the Prophets and Messengers, our Prophet Muhammad, the best of all His creation, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Allah has magnified it greatly and revered it immensely, describing it with the best attributes, characterizing it with the most majestic and greatest traits, and naming it with the most beautiful names. He, Glory be to Him, is the Initiator of its magnification, reverence, and exaltation. He, Glory be to Him, preserved it with Himself in a protected place approached only by the pure angels. He said in His description of it: {But this is an honored Quran. [Inscribed] in a Preserved Slate.} (Al-Buruj: 21-22). Then He combined its description and its protected place within it, the description of the angels who alone touch it, and the description of its Revealer, Glory be to Him, in His saying: {Indeed, it is a noble Quran. In a Register well-protected; None touch it except the purified. [It is] a revelation from the Lord of the worlds.} (Al-Waqi'a: 77-80). Due to the greatness of our Lord's speech, He selected the elite of His angels from the inhabitants of heaven to descend with it to the greatest and most noble spot on earth, upon the elite of His creation from the inhabitants of earth, in the mistress of nights of the master of months. He selected the most noble and purest of angels for its revelation, saying in description of the Noble Angel who descended with the Quran: {The Trustworthy Spirit has brought it down} (Al-Shu'ara: 193). Then He selected the purest of hearts to be the place of His speech's descent, so it would dwell in his heart to comprehend it, and He would preserve it for him therein, so he would fulfill its right within himself and in communicating it to his nation on behalf of his Lord to please Him. He said regarding that location upon which He sent it down and deposited it: {Upon your heart, [O Muhammad] - that you may be of the warners} (Al-Shu'ara: 194). And He said regarding that also: {For indeed, he has brought it down upon your heart by permission of Allah, confirming what came before it and as guidance and good tidings for the believers.} (Al-Baqarah: 97). This was in the greatest night, which our Lord described as a blessed night, saying: {Indeed, We sent it down during a blessed night. Indeed, We were to warn.} (Ad-Dukhan: 3). That night is the Night of Decree (Laylat al-Qadr), regarding which He said: {Indeed, We sent the Qur'an down during the Night of Decree. And what can make you know what is the Night of Decree? The Night of Decree is better than a thousand months.} (Al-Qadr: 1-3). This was in the best month, as our Lord said: {The month of Ramadhan [is that] in which was revealed the Quran, a guidance for the people and clear proofs of guidance and criterion.} (Al-Baqarah: 185). He made the beginning and end of its revelation in Makkah Al-Mukarramah near His Ancient House, about which He said: {Indeed, the first House [of worship] established for mankind was that at Bakkah - blessed and a guidance for the worlds.} (Al Imran: 96). And He made the conclusion of its revelation and the farewell of His revealed inspiration during the Farewell Pilgrimage in a sacred month,

Upon this reverence, glorification, and veneration for the speech of the Lord of the Worlds, the Noble Prophet raised his companions, may Allah be pleased with them. They loved the speech of Allah and stood with it in their prayer niches reciting it in groups and individually. They filled their times with it, adhered to its guidance, permitting what it permitted and forbidding what it forbade. They made it fill their hearts, hearing, and sight. They sought healing through it from physical and spiritual ailments, and referred to it for judgment in all their life affairs. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, passed to the Supreme Companion while the Quran was not collected in one place. When the Caliphate passed to the First Siddiq (Abu Bakr), may Allah be pleased with him, and seventy reciters were killed during his reign in the Wars of Apostasy at the Battle of Yamama, fearing the loss of the Quran with the loss of its carriers, he rose, may Allah be pleased with him, along with the multitudes of noble Companions, may Allah be pleased with them all, to perform one of the greatest deeds known in our glorious history: collecting the Quran between the two covers of a single Mushaf (volume). This research is a conveyance of a realistic, tangible scene of this great work undertaken by the first Siddiq of the Ummah, assisted by those great prominent figures from the first forerunners to Islam from the vanguard of this nation, may Allah be pleased with them all. Research Plan: The researcher has included in his research a plan consisting of four chapters, each chapter consisting of several sections, in which he clarified the following: First: The importance of the research topic. Second: The most important and prominent previous studies. Third: The reasons and motives for choosing the research topic. Fourth: The research problem and its objectives. Fifth: Research methodology. Sixth: Conclusion of the research, and a statement of the most important results reached by this concise study. Seventh: Collection of indexes. The research plan includes four chapters as follows: Chapter One: The motives for Abu Bakr's compilation, its causes, and reasons. It contains three sections: Section One: The beginning of the idea of compilation in the era of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq - may Allah be pleased with him. Section Two: The stance of the Companions regarding Abu Bakr's compilation of the Quran. Section Three: The most important motives for Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him. Chapter Two: Its characteristics and advantages. It contains four sections: Section One: The most prominent advantages of this compilation. Section Two: Explanation that the arrangement of verses within the Surahs is Tawqifi (divinely ordained). Section Three: Presentation of the opinions regarding the arrangement of the Surahs with preference between them. Section Four: The beginning of opposition and contradiction to the Mushaf order with the chronological order (order of revelation) and clarifying its source. Chapter Three: Statement of the conditions of Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him - and the manner in which it was done. It contains seven sections:

Research Methodology. First: Importance of the Research Topic. If the honor of knowledge comes from the honor of the known subject, then the topic of the research is related to the most honorable, greatest, and majestic book, the "Holy Quran" in general. Specifically, it relates to the issue of the compilation of the Quran in the era of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him. This issue troubled the elite of the first generation of Companions, who are the protectors of religion and heirs of prophetic knowledge, the best of this nation. They fulfilled the right of their Lord's Book appropriately and rose to collect it just as it was in its first era, free from addition and subtraction, free from alteration and change. Their compilation of the Quran was exactly in accordance with the first Prophetic compilation, but they collected it in one place after it had been scattered among palm stalks and thin stones, just as they collected it from what was memorized in the chests of men as well. Allah Almighty has guaranteed the preservation of the Holy Quran in all its stages of revelation. Evidences for this from the Book of Allah are many, including but not limited to: 1 - His saying regarding the general preservation: {Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian.} (Al-Hijr: 9), meaning from any addition or subtraction, and this is the saying of the generality of the Imams of Exegesis, and no opponent is known to it. 2 - Also His saying: {Falsehood cannot approach it from before it or from behind it.} (Fussilat: 42). Falsehood refers to Iblis; he cannot subtract truth from it nor add falsehood to it. (1) 3 - Also His saying: {And recite, [O Muhammad], what has been revealed to you of the Book of your Lord. There is no changer of His words, and never will you find in other than Him a refuge.} (Al-Kahf: 27). And His saying: {There is no changer of His words} means: no one to alter them, distort them, or misinterpret them. (2) The general evidences for this in the Book of Allah are too many to count. The Quran has been preserved by Allah Almighty in all stages of its revelation. Allah established and preserved it in the Preserved Tablet in Heaven before its descent, preserved it on its path of descent to the earth, and preserved it after its descent to the earth upon His Messenger, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Then Allah Almighty promised him to preserve it in his chest (heart), so his Lord reassured him by fulfilling His promise, saying to him: {Move not your tongue with it, [O Muhammad], to hasten with recitation of the Qur'an. Indeed, upon Us is its collection [in your heart] and [to make possible] its recitation. So when We have recited it [through Gabriel], then follow its recitation. Then upon Us is its clarification [to you].} (Al-Qiyamah: 16-19). Thus, it becomes clear to us that Allah Almighty preserved the Holy Quran while it was in Heaven, preserved it at the time of its descent from there, and preserved it after its descent to Earth. The collection of the Quran passed through three stages, and its collection in all stages was memorized in chests (hearts) and written in lines. As for the first stage: It was during the time of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. He was keen on preserving the Holy Quran, and Allah collected it for him in his chest. He also took care to teach it to his companions and encouraged them to memorize and master it. He adopted from the elite of their memorizers scribes of revelation who would write down everything revealed to him in his presence. The Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, passed to the Supreme Companion without the entire Quran being collected in one place during his life, neither in sheets (*Suhuf*) nor in volumes (*Masahif*). Rather, it was written scattered among patches (*Riqa'*), shoulder blades (*Aktaf*), palm stalks (*Usub*), and similar writing tools used in this blessed era. His strictness, peace be upon him, in not collecting the Quran between the two covers of a single sheet was in anticipation of renewed revelation and the successive descent of something new from it until his death. If he had arranged it as it came and collected the Quran in one place between the covers of one volume, it would have resulted in hardship and difficulty beyond imagination. This arrangement would have led to changes and alterations in the position of Surahs and verses whenever something new of revelation came down to him, peace be upon him. In this, there is obvious extreme hardship which the noble Sharia came to lift and repel. As for the second stage: It was during the era of Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him. The Holy Quran remained scattered, not collected between the covers of one volume, until the Caliphate passed to Abu Bakr, and the Wars of Apostasy arose. Killing intensified among the reciters in the Battle of Yamama - in the year twelve AH - in which seventy reciters from the memorizers of the Quran were killed. This matter alarmed Umar bin Al-Khattab, and he feared that some of the Quran might be lost with the death of its memorizers and reciters. So he advised Abu Bakr to collect the Quran for fear of losing part of it due to the killing of reciters and memorizers. This was the main motive for this collection. So Al-Siddiq proceeded to collect what was written scattered in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, from patches, shoulder blades, palm stalks, thin white stones (*Likhaf*), ribs, saddles, and boards into one place. His compilation, may Allah be pleased with him, was the same as what was written in the era of Prophethood, with verses and Surahs arranged, but he collected it in one place after it had been scattered. As for the third stage: It was during the era of Uthman bin Affan, may Allah be pleased with him. The reasons for collection in his era differed from the reasons for collection in the era of Al-Siddiq - may Allah be pleased with them both. The Companions used to recite the Quran according to the Seven Modes (*Ahruf*) which the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, had taught them, until differences occurred among the reciters during the conquests in the time of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him. The researcher suffices here with stating this stage briefly using what Al-Bukhari narrated from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him: That Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman came to Uthman while he was campaigning with the people of Sham in the conquest of Armenia and Azerbaijan with the people of Iraq. Their difference in recitation alarmed Hudhayfah, so Hudhayfah said to Uthman: "O Commander of the Faithful, save this nation before they differ in the Book like the difference of the Jews and Christians." So Uthman sent a message to Hafsa: "Send us the sheets (*Suhuf*) so we may copy them into the volumes (*Masahif*), then we will return them to you." So Hafsa sent them to Uthman. He ordered Zaid bin Thabit, Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, Sa'id bin Al-Aas, and Abdul Rahman bin Al-Harith bin Hisham, so they copied them into the volumes. Uthman said to the three Qurashi men: "If you and Zaid bin Thabit differ in anything of the Quran, write it in the dialect of Quraysh; for it was revealed in their dialect (meaning initially)." So they did so, until when they had copied the sheets into the volumes, Uthman returned the sheets to Hafsa, and sent to every region a volume from what they had copied, and ordered that everything else of the Quran in every sheet or volume be burned. Within the narrow limits of his research, the researcher did not find a grounded study that addressed the compilation of Al-Siddiq, may Allah be pleased with him, as an independent scientific research. However, it was addressed within the compilation of the Quran in its three stages in a number of scientific researches, most notably: First Study: "Compilation of the Quran in its Historical Stages from the Prophetic Era to the Modern Era", Author: Muhammad Shar'i Abu Zaid, Master's Thesis, Faculty of Sharia, Kuwait University, Year of Publication: 1419 AH. Description of the Research: This research highlights the Muslims' care for preserving the Quran from the era of Prophethood until now, and confirms that the transmission of the Quran received the highest degrees of care from Muslims. It responds to the doubts of detractors from the enemies of Islam regarding the transmission of the Holy Quran. Due to the quality of the research, its good phrasing, quality of presentation, cohesive style, and strength of argument, many researchers have benefited from it and drawn from it. Then in the second section, he discussed the compilation of Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him. As for the third section, he did not name it, and he addressed it in two requirements: the first requirement discussed the distinctive differences between the two compilations, and the second requirement discussed the Seven Modes (*Ahruf*) and their observance in the two compilations. The researcher should have observed important aspects and paid attention to them, most notably: 1 - An introduction to the compilation in the Prophetic era, even if in the preface, because it is the foundation upon which all stages of compilation were built, and due to the close connection of the compilation in the following two eras to it; however, he referred to it with a quick reference in just two lines. 2 - Attention to what Abu Amr Al-Dani went to in "Al-Urjuzah Al-Munabbihah" that Gabriel, peace be upon him, used to review the Quran with the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, every year with one of the Seven Letters, where he says: "And he used to present to Gabriel ... in every year the entirety of the revelation / So he would recite to him in every presentation ... one of the Seven Letters / Until when the time was near ... he presented it to him twice" (2). text: Third: Reasons and Motives for Choosing the Research Topic. Bringing Sciences of the Quran closer through an accessible scientific style is one of the main reasons driving the choice of the research topic. Additionally, the compilation of the Quran in its three eras still needs approximation, verification, and scrutiny in some of its issues to clarify them to the public, shedding light on what was transmitted correctly generation after generation while pointing out unproven traditions related to the research topic. The researcher chose to address Al-Siddiq's compilation with research and study because he did not find, within the limits of his search, a study dedicated to this compilation. The researcher also desired to highlight the aspect of complete care, investigation, and precision that the compilation of the Quran met in the era of Al-Siddiq, upon which the Ummah (Muslim nation), predecessors and successors, agreed regarding its correctness, precision, and integrity. Fourth: Research Problem and Objectives. There are problems related to the research topic, most notably: 1 - Why was the Quran not collected in one place during the Prophetic era? 2 - Did Al-Siddiq's compilation differ from the compilation in the Prophetic era? 3 - Is collecting the Quran in one place considered an innovation in religion? 4 - Did Al-Siddiq's compilation, may Allah be pleased with him, include the Seven Modes (*Ahruf*)? 5 - Was the arrangement of verses in the Surahs by divine instruction (*Tawqifi*) from the Prophet, peace be upon him, or was it by the diligence (*Ijtihad*) of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them? One of the most prominent objectives of the research was to highlight these incoming problems and solve them by shedding light on them and addressing them with research, study, verification, and scrutiny. Fifth: Research Methodology. The researcher followed more than one research methodology in addressing his research, most notably: 1 - Inductive Analytical Method 2 - Critical Method 3 - Historical Method. In the First Chapter: The researcher induced the motives for Abu Bakr's compilation, its causes and reasons, and linked the relationship between it and the first compilation in the Prophetic era. In the Second Chapter: The researcher presented the characteristics and advantages of this compilation analytically by inducing those advantages that distinguished this compilation. Then he addressed the arrangement of verses in the Surahs, presenting the opinions mentioned therein and then preferring between them. Then he induced after that the beginning of opposition and contradiction to the Mushaf order with the chronological order (order of revelation) and clarified its source, presenting all of that analytically, then critiquing and refuting it.

(1) Section Two: The stance of the Companions regarding Abu Bakr's compilation of the Quran. The Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - fully realized and were completely certain that Allah Almighty's promise never fails, and He, Glory be to Him, promised to preserve His Book from change and alteration and from addition or subtraction by His saying Glory be to Him: {Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian} (Al-Hijr: 9). They also realized that Allah's cosmic laws have causes that uphold them, and realized through those laws also that this religion does not stand by itself but must have human supporters and helpers who carry on their shoulders its support, carrying its message, and defending its domains. Therefore, they - may Allah be pleased with them - performed their duty towards it by exerting the causes to preserve the Book of their Lord from loss and disappearance. This stems from the strength of their faith in Allah and His Messenger, the breadth of their knowledge of their Lord's religion, their understanding of His law and methodology, and their realization of the greatness of the trust upon their necks, and the magnitude of the responsibility placed on their shoulders. Is Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him - of the Quran considered a religious innovation (*Bid'ah*)? The concept of Innovation (*Bid'ah*) in Language: Let us know first that *Bid'ah* in language is taken from *Bad'*, which is invention without a prior example. From it is His saying Almighty: {Originator (*Badi'*) of the heavens and the earth} [Al-Baqarah: 117], meaning their Inventor without a prior example. And His saying Almighty: {Say, "I am not something original (*Bid'an*) among the messengers} [Al-Ahqaf: 9], meaning: I was not the first to come with a message from Allah to the servants, but many messengers preceded me. It is said: So-and-so invented an innovation (*Ibtada'a Bid'ah*), meaning: he initiated a way not preceded to. Fourth: The Prophet - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - used to have his scribes write it by his dictation to them. Is it hidden from anyone envisioning a correct meaning in his heart that this was an alert to writing it and controlling it by recording in sheets? If what Allah guaranteed of its preservation meant no action for the Ummah in it, the Messenger of Allah - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - would not have written it after Allah informed him of the guarantee of its preservation. But it was known that its preservation is from Allah through our preservation, His facilitating that for us, and His teaching of its writing and control in sheets among us. Fifth: It is established: "That the Prophet - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - forbade traveling with the Quran to the land of the enemy" (1); this is an alert that it is written among the Ummah, accompanied in travels. Abu Bakr bin Al-Arabi (d. 543 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - said in Ahkam al-Quran: This is one of the clearest faces for observers." (2) Al-Baqillani (d. 402 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - also said: Umar understood that the Prophet's - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - leaving of its collection did not indicate prohibition, and Abu Bakr returned (to this view) when he saw the facet of correctness in that... (3) Al-Baqillani's speech above is precious speech containing clear evidences and decisive arguments with which all incoming doubts are refuted. Praise be to Allah, Lord of the Earth and Heavens. Al-Shatibi (d. 790 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - said in Al-Muwafaqat: The sum of the matter is that the collection of the Mushaf was silent about in his time - peace be upon him. (4) The Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - are the best of this nation, the most honoring of Allah, His religion, and His law, and the furthest from innovation and introducing into Allah's religion what is not of it. Sheikh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyyah (d. 728 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "... Thus were the Companions and those who followed their path of the Successors in goodness and the Imams of Muslims. Therefore, none of them opposed texts with his intellect, nor established a religion other than what the Messenger brought. If he wanted to know something of religion and speak about it, he looked into what Allah and the Messenger said; from it he learns, by it he speaks, into it he looks and thinks, and by it he is enlightened. This is the principle of Ahl al-Sunnah." text: bin Asim (d. 18 AH) may Allah be pleased with him (that) he said: I heard the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, saying: "Indeed Allah Almighty has protected my Ummah for me from three: that they do not starve, that they do not gather on error, and that the heartland of Muslims is not violated." (1) From the Hadith of Ibn Umar (d. 73 AH) may Allah be pleased with them both: He said: The Messenger of Allah - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - said: "Indeed Allah Almighty does not gather my Ummah on error, and Allah's hand is over the congregation (*Jama'ah*)." (2) And from Yusayr bin Amr who said: I heard Ibn Masud - may Allah be pleased with him - saying: "Stick to the congregation, for Allah does not gather the Ummah of Muhammad - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - on error." (3) This undoubtedly has the ruling of being raised (to the Prophet), nay, it is completely consistent with it. The protection of this mercified Nation is a general protection preventing them from agreeing on error; meaning: they do not agree on a matter containing clear error and manifest opposition to the Sunnah leading them to destruction and blindness. Section Three: The most important motives for Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him. The most important motives and reasons for this compilation were: 1 - One of the most important motives pushing the Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - to collect the Quran was the cessation of revelation from Heaven by the death of the Prophet - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - that great calamity and momentous event which caused fear for the loss of the Quran. 2 - Also prominent is the intensification of killing among the reciters of the Quran and its memorizers on the Day of Yamama. Their killing raised fears of the loss of their Lord's Book. Additionally, they were liable to disperse and spread in the regions for Jihad in the path of Allah, and for calling to Islam and spreading it in the corners of the globe, and for teaching people the matter of their religion, because they are a nation of communication, call, and Jihad, not a nation of sleep and slumber. Therefore, Umar said to Abu Bakr - may Allah be pleased with them both: "The killing has intensified on the Day of Yamama among the reciters of the Quran, and I fear that killing will intensify among the reciters in the battlefields, so much of the Quran might be lost." The loss of some reciters might mean the loss of others, so by this action, the matter could be rectified from its beginning. (4) "The Battle of Yamama was a fierce battle in which many reciter Companions and memorizers of the Quran were martyred, their number reaching seventy, and some put it at five hundred, among them Salim, client of Abu Hudhayfah." (5) So "... recording the Quran and binding it by writing, collected and arranged, fearing the loss of any part of it by the death of its carriers and memorizers" was done. (6) Chapter Two: Its characteristics and advantages. It contains four sections: Section One: The most prominent advantages of this compilation. Section Two: Explanation that the arrangement of verses in the Surahs is Tawqifi (divinely ordained). Section Three: Presentation of the opinions regarding the arrangement of the Surahs with preference between them. Section Four: The beginning of opposition and contradiction to the Mushaf order with the chronological order (order of revelation) and clarifying its source. text: First: Its precision and integrity. Second: Its fulfillment of the agreed-upon compilation conditions and its conformity with the Final Review (*Ardah Akhirah*). Most prominent features and characteristics of Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him - in detail: First: Its precision and integrity. Investigation, scrutiny, verification, and authentication of the Quranic nature of every collected Surah and verse, proving its Mutawatir transmission, restricting it to what its recitation was not abrogated, and stripping it of anything not Quran, was the most prominent characteristic of this compilation, by the consensus of the Companions - may Allah be pleased with them. Second: Its fulfillment of the agreed-upon compilation conditions and its conformity with the Final Review. Everything that met the agreed-upon compilation conditions was added to a single sheet in one place, which was later known as the Mushaf. Its verses and Surahs were arranged according to the Mushaf order, not the order of revelation (*Nuzuli*), in accordance with the Final Review which it was rumored that Zaid bin Thabit (1) may Allah be pleased with him had witnessed. That compilation conforms to what is established in the Preserved Tablet. It is established in Al-Bukhari and others from Aisha from Fatimah - may Allah be pleased with them both - that she said: "The Prophet, peace be upon him, confided to me that Gabriel used to review the Quran with him every year, and that he reviewed it with me twice this year, and I do not see it but that my term has approached." (2) (3) Regarding that, Abu Abdul Rahman Al-Sulami (d. 74) may Allah have mercy on him says: Zaid bin Thabit recited to the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, twice in the year Allah took his soul. This recitation was named the recitation of Zaid bin Thabit because he wrote it for the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, recited it to him, witnessed the Final Review, and taught people with it until he died. Therefore, Abu Bakr and Umar relied on him in its collection, and Uthman appointed him to write the Mushafs. (4) Similarly, Abu Amr Al-Dani - may Allah have mercy on him - says in Al-Urjuzah Al-Munabbihah: (5) "And he used to present to Gabriel ... in every year the entirety of the revelation / So he would recite to him in every presentation ... one of the Seven Letters (6) / Until when the time was near ... he presented it to him twice" (7). Al-Qastallani (d. 923 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - says: "The entire Quran was written in his era - peace be upon him - but not collected in one place, nor were the Surahs arranged." (8) This is because the motives for collecting it in one place were lacking, and there was no urgent necessity for it at that time. Section Two: Explanation that the arrangement of verses in the Surahs is Tawqifi (divinely ordained). The arrangement of verses in the Surahs is a Tawqifi matter with no room for Ijtihad (reasoning) whatsoever. Al-Zarkashi (d. 794 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - said: As for the verses in every Surah, and placing the Basmalah at their beginnings, their arrangement is Tawqifi without doubt, and there is no dispute in it; therefore, reversing it is not permissible. As for Consensus (*Ijma'*), it was reported by more than one, including Al-Zarkashi in Al-Burhan, and Abu Ja'far bin Al-Zubayr in his Munasabat; his phrase is: The arrangement of verses in their Surahs occurred by his instruction - peace be upon him - and his command, without disagreement on this among Muslims. (2) Al-Zurqani (d. 1367 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "The consensus of scholars was convened that the arrangement of verses in the Surah was by instruction (*Tawqif*) from the Prophet - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - from Allah Almighty, and there is no room for opinion and Ijtihad in it, and no opponent is known in that." (3) Among those who stated the Consensus narrated by Al-Suyuti and Al-Zurqani as well are: 1 - Ibn Qudamah Al-Maqdisi (d. 620 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: Arrangement of verses is obligatory; because their arrangement is by text by consensus. (4) 2 - And Abu Ja'far Al-Gharnati (d. 708 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: Know first that the arrangement of verses in their Surahs occurred by his instruction and command - peace be upon him, without disagreement on this among Muslims. (5) 3 - And Mulla Ali Al-Qari (d. 1014 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: Arrangement of verses is Tawqifi, and upon it is Consensus. (6) 4 - And Shihab al-Din Al-Nafrawi (d. 1127 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: Arrangement of verses is Tawqifi by agreement. (7) This is also indicated by many evidences from the authentic confirmed Sunnah from the Infallible, peace be upon him, which are too many to count. We mention among them, for example but not limited to: 1 - What Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih from Ibn Abi Mulaykah who said: Ibn Al-Zubayr said: I said to Uthman regarding this verse in Al-Baqarah {And those who are taken in death among you and leave wives} up to his saying {without expulsion} (Al-Baqarah verse: 240): The other one abrogated it, so why do you write it? He said: Leave it, O son of my brother, I do not change anything from it from its place. (8) The response of Uthman bin Affan to Ibn Al-Zubayr implies that they - may Allah be pleased with them all - knew the places of verse arrangement, so Uthman left it fixed in its place because the context indicates it, and because it is what they learned and what was practiced among them. 2 - What Muslim narrated in his Sahih from Umar who said: I did not ask the Prophet, peace be upon him, about anything more than I asked him about *Kalalah* (inheritance of one with no direct heirs) until he poked his finger in my chest and said: Does not the verse of Summer which is at the end of Surah Al-Nisa suffice you? (9) The verse of *Kalalah* is located at the end of Surah Al-Nisa and its conclusions. When Umar - may Allah be pleased with him - asked the Messenger of Allah - peace be upon him - he guided him to its place at the end of the Surah. From here, two things become clear to us: First matter: That the verses of the Surah are arranged and consecutive from its beginning to its end. Second matter: That the arrangement of verses was something the Prophet - peace be upon him - taught his noble companions - may Allah be pleased with them.

text: Among those Surahs revealed all at once is Surah Bara'ah (Tawbah): Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih from Al-Bara' - may Allah be pleased with him - who said: "The last Surah revealed completely (*Kamilah*) was Bara'ah." (1) Al-Bukhari also narrated it (2) with the wording: "The last Surah revealed was Bara'ah..." without the word "completely". Some scholars held that Surah Bara'ah was revealed in parts and not all at once, claiming the incorrectness of the word "completely". Badr al-Din al-Ayni - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "His saying: (completely), Al-Dawudi said: The wording 'completely' is naught because Bara'ah was revealed bit by bit. I say: That is why the wording 'completely' was not mentioned in this hadith in (the Book of) Tafsir, and its wording there is: The last Surah revealed was Bara'ah." (3) However, Al-Tahir bin Ashur mentioned in "Al-Tahrir wa Al-Tanwir" that it was revealed all at once, attributing this view to the majority of scholars. (4) Among those Surahs revealed all at once is also Surah Al-Fath: Al-Bukhari narrated in his Sahih from Umar - may Allah be pleased with him - from the Prophet, peace be upon him, who said: (Tonight a Surah has been revealed to me which is dearer to me than that upon which the sun rises) then he recited: {Indeed, We have given you a clear conquest} (Al-Fath: 1). (5) Among those Surahs revealed all at once is also Surah Al-Bayyinah: From Ammar bin Abi Ammar, he said: I heard Abu Habbah Al-Badri say: When {Those who disbelieved among the People of the Scripture were not...} [Al-Bayyinah: 1] to its end was revealed, Gabriel - peace be upon him - said: O Messenger of Allah, indeed your Lord commands you to recite it to Ubayy. So the Prophet - peace be upon him - said to Ubayy: (Indeed Gabriel commanded me to recite this Surah to you). Ubayy said: Was I mentioned there, O Messenger of Allah? He said: (Yes). He said: So Ubayy wept. (6) Also from the Surahs revealed all at once is Surah Al-Kawthar: From Anas, he said: While the Messenger of Allah - peace be upon him - was among us one day, he dozed off, then raised his head smiling. We said: What makes you laugh, O Messenger of Allah? He said: "A Surah was revealed to me just now." So he recited: {In the name of Allah, the Entirely Merciful, the Especially Merciful. Indeed, We have granted you, [O Muhammad], al-Kawthar. So pray to your Lord and sacrifice. Indeed, your enemy is the one cut off.} (Al-Kawthar complete: 1-3). (7) Also from the Surahs revealed all at once is Surah Al-Nasr: From Ubaydullah bin Abdullah bin Utbah, he said: Ibn Abbas said to me: Do you know the last Surah revealed from the Quran, revealed entirely? (8) Also from the Surahs revealed all at once is Surah Al-Masad: It is established in the Two Sahihs from Abbas - may Allah be pleased with them both - who said: The Prophet - peace be upon him - climbed Al-Safa one day and said: (O Morning Warning!), so Quraysh gathered to him. They said: What is with you? He said: (If I told you that the enemy attacks you in the morning or evening, would you believe me?) They said: Yes. text: Also from the Surahs revealed all at once are the two Mu'awwidhatayn (Al-Falaq and Al-Nas): From Uqbah bin Amir, he said: The Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, said: "Have you not seen verses revealed tonight the likes of which have never been seen? {Say, I seek refuge in the Lord of daybreak} and {Say, I seek refuge in the Lord of mankind}." (1) The summary of the above: The revelation of many short Surahs of the Mufassal all at once is a matter established by explicit authentic evidences, such as Al-Fatihah, Al-Qadr, Al-Ma'un, Al-Masad, Al-Kawthar, Al-Fil, Al-Nasr, Al-Kafirun, Al-Ikhlas, Al-Falaq, and Al-Nas. As well as Al-Fath. As for what some exegetes mentioned that several Surahs were revealed all at once as well, especially from the long ones, most of those statements are matters of consideration and deduction, and the disagreement in them is known because they are opinions based on reasoning not supported by clear argument from authentic explicit established evidence; therefore, the researcher mentioned only what was established to him by authentic explicit established evidence. Note: It must be known that the principle in the Holy Quran is that it was collected and arranged on the basis of its conformity with the Final Review (*Ardah Akhirah*), and the Final Review settled on what is established and conforming to what is in the Preserved Tablet as well. Section Three: Presentation of opinions regarding the arrangement of Surahs with preference between them. Al-Suyuti - may Allah have mercy on him - says in Al-Itqan regarding the disagreement on the arrangement of Surahs: As for the arrangement of Surahs as they are now in the Mushaf, scholars of this field differed on three schools of thought: First School: The view of the majority, which sees that the arrangement of Surahs is a Tawfiqi (divinely guided/success granted) matter from the Ijtihad (reasoning) of the Companions, as the Prophet, peace be upon him, delegated that to his Ummah after him. Among the most prominent who leaned towards this opinion is Imam Malik. Second School: Views that this arrangement is Tawqifi (instruction) from the Prophet, peace be upon him. A group of scholars held this view. Third School: Leans towards the view that the arrangement of most Surahs was by instruction (*Tawqif*) from the Prophet, peace be upon him, and was known in his life, and that the arrangement of some Surahs was by Ijtihad of the Companions. (2) We passed earlier what Al-Suyuti mentioned of scholars' opinions on the arrangement of Surahs in general. The disagreement on this issue is very wide and has major importance due to its relation to a great matter concerning the Book of Allah Almighty. Proponents of each view cited evidences for what they preferred. Major Imams whose opinion is relied upon spoke on this issue. The topic is not a main research in our subject, and the researcher did not cite the evidences of each group to discuss them for fear of prolongation in a side research from the main research topic, even though it is of great importance due to its status and value

Many Imams see that the arrangement of the Holy Quran's Surahs was a Tawqifi (divinely ordained) arrangement just as the arrangement of its verses was. They cited clear evidences and compelling arguments that make the researcher pause long at them and reconsider, research, and look into them much. Among the most prominent of these opinions are: First Opinion: The saying of Al-Zarkashi (d. 794 AH) in Al-Burhan - may Allah have mercy on him: "Some of our investigative Sheikhs said: He who said: No correlation is sought for the noble verse because they are according to scattered events has erred. The decisive speech is that it is according to events in revelation, and according to wisdom in arrangement. The Mushaf is like the Noble Sheets conforming to what is in the Hidden Book, all its Surahs and verses arranged by Tawqif (instruction)... I say: This is built on the fact that the arrangement of Surahs is Tawqifi, and this is the preponderant view." (1) Undoubtedly, such a statement from Al-Zarkashi has its scientific value, status, and worth, due to his discussion of each group's evidence on one hand, and his mastery of this science on the other. Second Opinion: The saying of Al-Suyuti (d. 911 AH) in Al-Itqan - may Allah have mercy on him: "Among what indicates it is Tawqifi is that the 'Ha-Mim' Surahs (Hawamim) were arranged consecutively, and likewise the 'Ta-Sin' Surahs (Tawasin), but the 'Musabbihat' (Surahs starting with Tasbih) were not arranged consecutively; rather, separation occurred between their Surahs. And separation was made between 'Ta-Sin-Mim' of Al-Shu'ara and 'Ta-Sin-Mim' of Al-Qasas by 'Ta-Sin' (Al-Naml) even though it is shorter than them. If the arrangement were Ijtihad, the Musabbihat would have been mentioned consecutively, and 'Ta-Sin' delayed after Al-Qasas." (2) Third Opinion: The saying of Abu Bakr Al-Ambari (d. 328 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: "The consistency of Surahs is like the consistency of verses and letters; all is from the Prophet, peace be upon him. So whoever advances a Surah or delays it has corrupted the organization of the Quran." (3) Fourth Opinion: The saying of Al-Kirmani: (d. 893 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him: "The arrangement of Surahs thus is with Allah in the Preserved Tablet in this order." (4) Fifth Opinion: The saying of Sharaf al-Din Al-Tibi (d. 743 AH) also - may Allah have mercy on him: "The Quran was revealed first as a whole from the Preserved Tablet to the Lowest Heaven, then revealed separately according to interests, then established in the Mushafs according to the composition and organization established in the Preserved Tablet." (5) Sixth Opinion: The saying of Muhibb al-Din Al-Nuwayri (d. 857 AH) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: "He (Uthman) ordered them to copy from the sheets (*Suhuf*) only so his Mushaf would rely on Abu Bakr's original which relied on the Prophet's original - peace be upon him. He appointed Zaid due to Abu Bakr and Umar's reliance on him, and joined a group to help him, and so number would join probity. These were the ones; due to their fame for precision and knowledge. They wrote it as one hundred and fourteen Surahs, the first being 'Al-Hamd' and the last 'Al-Nas' on this order." (6) It is clear from Al-Nuwayri's words that he sees Abu Bakr's copying was complete with arranged verses

Tenth Opinion: The saying of Mulla Ali Al-Qari (4) where he says - may Allah have mercy on him: Yet the more correct view is that the arrangement of Surahs is also Tawqifi, even if their Mushafs differed in that before the Final Review... "O you who ask me about the Book of Allah diligently... And about the arrangement of what is recited of Surahs
And how the Chosen One from Mudar brought them... May God bless the Chosen One from Mudar" (1)
Ibn Al-Hassar indicates that the arrangement of Surahs was brought by the Prophet - peace be upon him, which is a clear indication from his speech that the arrangement of Surahs is Tawqifi from him - peace be upon him. Eleventh Opinion: A collection of statements from some contemporaries. A group of contemporaries also preferred the view of Tawqif, and they are, for example but not limited to: "It came in Al-Tafsir Al-Wasit: The arrangement of Surahs is as it came in the Noble Mushaf by the command of Allah Almighty (2). 1 - The author of Al-Tafsir Al-Wasit said: What the soul leans towards is that the arrangement of Surahs is Tawqifi, and that every Surah has its subjects which we see prominent in a way distinguishing it from others (3). 2 - Wahbah bin Mustafa Al-Zuhayli (d. 1436 AH) said: There is no disagreement among scholars that the arrangement of verses of Surahs is Tawqifi, transmitted and established from the Prophet, peace be upon him, just as the arrangement of Surahs is also Tawqifi according to the preponderant view (4). Among those who said this as well among contemporaries are Muhammad Abdullah Draz and Ahmed Shakir. Among the most prominent evidences used by some of these for the Tawqif of the Mushaf arrangement are: 1 - The consensus of the Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - on the arrangement of Surahs in the Uthmani Mushaf. If this arrangement were Ijtihadi (based on reasoning), they would not have agreed on it, would have held onto their Mushafs, would not have offered them for burning, and would not have united on the Imam Mushaf. "Uthman bin Affan - may Allah be pleased with him - burned the Mushafs in which disagreement occurred, and kept for them the agreed upon, as established in the Final Review." (5) It is established in Al-Bukhari from Anas bin Malik, may Allah be pleased with him, that Hudhayfah bin Al-Yaman, may Allah be pleased with him, came to Uthman, may Allah be pleased with him, while he was campaigning with the people of Sham in the conquest of Armenia and Azerbaijan with the people of Iraq. Their difference in recitation alarmed Hudhayfah, so Hudhayfah said to Uthman: "O Commander of the Faithful, save this nation before they differ in the Book like the difference of the Jews and Christians." So Uthman sent to Hafsa: "Send us the sheets (*Suhuf*) so we may copy them into the volumes (*Masahif*), then we will return them to you." So Hafsa sent them to Uthman. He ordered Zaid bin Thabit, Abdullah bin Al-Zubayr, Sa'id bin Al-Aas, and Abdul Rahman bin Al-Harith bin Hisham, so they copied them into the volumes. Uthman said to the three Qurashi men: "If you and Zaid bin Thabit differ in anything of the Quran, write it in the dialect of Quraysh; for it was revealed in their dialect (meaning initially)." So they did so until when they had copied the sheets into the volumes, Uthman returned the sheets to Hafsa, and sent to every region a volume from what they had copied, and ordered that everything else of the Quran in every sheet or volume be burned. text: Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, said: "O people, do not exaggerate regarding Uthman, and say nothing but good about him regarding the Mushafs and the burning of the Mushafs. By Allah, he did not do what he did regarding the Mushafs except with the consultation of all of us." (1) The saying of Ali bin Abi Talib, may Allah be pleased with him, indicates that they agreed upon it with a silent consensus - may Allah be pleased with them all. Stance of Ibn Masud - may Allah be pleased with him: Ibn Kathir - may Allah have mercy on him - said: "It was narrated about Abdullah bin Masud that he was angry when his Mushaf was taken from him and burned, and he spoke about his precedence in Islam over Zaid bin Thabit who wrote the Mushafs. So Uthman bin Affan - may Allah be pleased with him - wrote to him inviting him to follow the Companions in what they agreed upon of interest in that, uniting the word, and lack of disagreement. So Abdullah bin Masud turned back, answered the call to follow, and left opposition - may Allah be pleased with them all." (2) Ibn Masud's response - may Allah be pleased with him - to follow in submitting his Mushaf for burning strengthens what we mentioned earlier of Ali bin Abi Talib's saying - may Allah be pleased with him; it strengthens, confirms, and reinforces the statement of silent consensus on one hand, and establishes actual consensus on the other hand as well. So may Allah be pleased with them all. Regarding that, Al-Zurqani (d. 1367 AH) says in his Manahil - while reviewing the evidences of proponents of Tawqif: "The arrangement of all Surahs is Tawqifi by the instruction of the Messenger - peace be upon him - like the arrangement of verses, and no Surah was placed in its position except by his order, peace be upon him. Proponents of this view argued that the Companions agreed on the Mushaf written in the era of Uthman and none of them dissented. Their consensus is not complete unless the arrangement they agreed upon was by instruction (*Tawqif*), because if it were by Ijtihad, the owners of differing Mushafs would have held onto their difference. But they did not hold onto it; rather they turned away from it and their arrangement, abandoned their Mushafs and burned them, and returned to Uthman's Mushaf and its arrangement entirely. Then they cited narrations for their school as evidences supporting the consensus." (3) If we concede for the sake of argument that the arrangement of the Mushaf was initially an Ijtihadi (reasoning-based) arrangement not Tawqifi, we would say that the consensus of the Nation has settled on the Mushaf arrangement, such that all books of exegesis follow this matter; we know of no opponent among the predecessors and successors, except that three contemporaries deviated from that, and mention of them will come in the next section God willing. Therefore, it is not permissible, such being the case, to violate this work upon which the Nation agreed. The meaning here refers to books of exegesis, because the matter of Mushafs (physical copies) no one dares to oppose at all, except what some Orientalists called for as will be explained. 2 - The Companions' partitioning (*Tahzib*) of the Quran. Also among what they used as evidence that the arrangement of Surahs is Tawqifi is the partitioning of the Quran. Then Ibn Hajar said: "This indicates that the arrangement of Surahs as it is in the Mushaf now was existing in the era of the Prophet - peace be upon him." (1) This is also clear evident proof mentioned by Al-Hafiz in Al-Fath, inferring that the arrangement of Surahs as it is in the Mushaf now was likewise in the era of its first revelation during the time of the Prophet, peace be upon him. 3 - The orderly arrangement of some Surahs similar in their opening. Regarding that, Al-Suyuti - may Allah have mercy on him - says: "Among what indicates it is Tawqifi is that the 'Ha-Mim' Surahs (Hawamim) were arranged consecutively, and likewise the 'Ta-Sin' Surahs (Tawasin), but the 'Musabbihat' were not arranged consecutively; rather, separation occurred between their Surahs. And separation was made between 'Ta-Sin-Mim' of Al-Shu'ara and 'Ta-Sin-Mim' of Al-Qasas by 'Ta-Sin' (Al-Naml) even though it is shorter than them. If the arrangement were Ijtihad, the Musabbihat would have been mentioned consecutively, and 'Ta-Sin' delayed after Al-Qasas." (2) This was mentioned when presenting the opinions of those stating the arrangement of Surahs is Tawqifi. This precise arrangement mentioned by Al-Suyuti for Surahs similar in their opening and introduction, and the manner of their arrangement and sequence with that extreme precision regarding "Al-Ha-Mim" Surahs and "Al-Ta-Sin-Mim" Surahs; since the seven "Al-Ha-Mim" Surahs were arranged consecutively, and likewise the three "Al-Ta-Sin-Mim" Surahs. As for the seven Musabbihat Surahs, despite the similarity of their opening, they did not come consecutively. And his saying: (and Ta-Sin was delayed) means Al-Naml opened with (Ta-Sin) was delayed after Al-Shu'ara (?) so it came after it, and fell between Surahs Al-Shu'ara and Al-Qasas which are similar in opening with (Ta-Sin-Mim). Zaid - may Allah be pleased with him - was adorned and beautified with self-virtues and high components of faith qualifying him to undertake this great task and bear its responsibility. These include activity, strength, and vitality accompanied by soundness of mind, piety, honesty, and godliness coupled with boldness in truth along with veneration of Allah's rituals. In addition to his bearing of responsibility and knowledge of the magnitude of the task, all this with his mastery and memorization of the Quran coupled with the availability of previous experience in performing the same task, which is writing revelation for the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. There is no doubt that those qualities he possessed helped him in precise investigation in collecting the Holy (Book) in the required manner befitting the status of the Book of Allah Almighty, striving to realize the promise of Allah Almighty which never fails, about which He said: {Indeed, it is We who sent down the Qur'an and indeed, We will be its guardian} (Al-Hijr: 9). Let us contemplate what is established in the Jami' Sahih in the famous Hadith narrated by Al-Bukhari with his chain from Zaid bin Thabit - may Allah be pleased with him - who said: Abu Bakr sent for me after the heavy killing of the people of Yamama, and Umar bin Al-Khattab was with him. Abu Bakr - may Allah be pleased with him - said: Umar came to me and said: 'The killing has intensified on the Day of Yamama among the reciters of the Quran, and I fear that killing will intensify among the reciters in the battlefields, so much of the Quran might be lost. I see that you should order the collection of the Quran.' I said to Umar: 'How can you do something that the Messenger of Allah - may Allah bless him and grant him peace - did not do?' Umar said: 'This, by Allah, is good.' Umar kept urging me until Allah opened my chest to that, and I saw regarding that what Umar saw. Zaid said: Abu Bakr said: 'You are a young, intelligent man, we do not accuse you, and you used to write the revelation for the Messenger of Allah - may Allah bless him and grant him peace. So track down the Quran and collect it.' By Allah, if they had charged me with moving a mountain of the mountains, it would not have been heavier upon me than what he ordered me of collecting the Quran. I said: 'How can you do something the Messenger of Allah, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, did not do?' He said: 'It, by Allah, is good.' Abu Bakr kept urging me until Allah opened my chest to that which He opened the chest of Abu Bakr and Umar - may Allah be pleased with them both - for. So I tracked down the Quran, collecting it from palm stalks (*Usub*), thin white stones (*Likhaf*), and the chests of men, until I found the end of Surah At-Tawbah with Abu Khuzaima Al-Ansari, I did not find it with anyone else: {There has certainly come to you a Messenger from among yourselves. Fourth: The collection of Al-Siddiq - may Allah be pleased with him - did not imply a type of compulsion for Muslims and forcing them to this collection and adhering to it. Therefore, some Companions who did not witness the Final Review did not know about the abrogation of some verses, so they used to read some abrogated parts of the Quran which they heard from the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him, without knowing of the later abrogation settled in the Final Review. Fifth: It is difficult to be certain and decisive that Al-Siddiq's collection - may Allah be pleased with him - included the Seven Modes. What inevitably indicates this is that there are words where writing alone is not sufficient; there must be a combination of writing and the correct method of pronouncing them, and there is no way for that at all except by sound. Let us take for example the word "Al-Sirat" which is written in all Mushafs with 'Sad' (الصراط), and has been read with 'Zay' as Ishmam (mixing the sound of Sad with Zay), meaning smelling the Sad with Zay; Khalaf narrated this from Hamzah. The reliance in it is on sound in pronunciation not on the drawn script. Say likewise regarding Imala, Taqil, Idgham and similar things which cannot be controlled except by transmission and vocal control. There is no doubt that these matters were not reported or preserved to be contained in Al-Siddiq's collection. Whoever claims otherwise, let him bring a bright proof and decisive evidence. The most that can be said in that is that Al-Siddiq's collection - may Allah be pleased with him - did not neglect modes of reading according to the script (Rasm), because his collection was not via what was written in lines only, but relied also on its conformity to what is memorized in chests. That is because the principle in reading the Quran is its transmission and reception by oral transmission. It is not understood from this that his collection bore only one aspect of script (Rasm) and thus neglected applying other modes of reading that the script bears; for such is not transmitted except via reception and oral transmission, not via written script. This is because taking reading by reception and oral transmission judges the script. Therefore, the Companions when writing the sheets did not consider the difference of script but considered reading first and made it judge and ruler over the script, considering that it is the origin and the script follows it. The saying that the Seven Modes are established in the Bakri Sheets is a saying lacking clear decisive proof and authentic established evidence to rely upon. Section Six: Abu Bakr's methodology which he set for "Zaid bin Thabit" in collecting and recording the Holy Quran. Al-Siddiq - may Allah be pleased with him - followed a tight approach and a perfected method that reached a great level of precision, tightness, and mastery in collecting the Holy Quran. Then he ordered Zaid - may Allah be pleased with him - to collect the Quran according to the plan and method he set for him, which contained precaution and placing guarantees and safety to protect the Book of Allah, and adhering to caution, precision, deliberation, and verification. He - may Allah be pleased with him - was not satisfied with what was memorized in his chest nor with what he wrote with his hand nor with what he heard with his ear. Rather, he began tracking and investigating all causes of verification, precision, mastery, and precaution, taking upon himself reliance on two main sources: First Source: What is written in lines, which is what was written in the presence of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him. - Second Source: What is memorized in chests, which is what was preserved in the chests of the Companions, may Allah be pleased with them. text: Memorization and Writing. Al-Sakhawi (d. 902 AH) - may Allah have mercy on him - clarifies the meaning of two witnesses saying: It means two just men testifying that that written material was written in the presence of the Messenger of Allah - may Allah bless him and grant him peace. Zaid did not rely on memorization alone; therefore he said in the Hadith narrated by Al-Bukhari: He did not find the end of Surah Bara'ah except with Abu Khuzaima; meaning: he did not find it written except with Abu Khuzaima Al-Ansari, even though Zaid memorized it, and many Companions memorized it. But he wanted to combine memorization and writing, for extra authentication and exaggeration in precaution. Upon this rational methodology, it was completed under the supervision of Abu Bakr and Umar and senior Companions and the consensus of the Nation on it without denial. That was an eternal virtue history still mentions with gratitude for Abu Bakr in supervision, for Umar in suggestion, for Zaid in execution, and for the Companions in assistance and approval." (1) What Al-Sakhawi - may Allah have mercy on him - concluded his speech with above should be written with eye-water (gold). We conclude this section by summarizing how Zaid executed the task of collecting the Quran in the following points: First: Al-Farooq (Umar) announced to people to bring what they had of the Quran written. Second: Zaid and Al-Farooq sat at the door of the mosque receiving what the Companions brought of the Quran. This is narrated with a disconnected chain as Al-Hafiz indicated in Al-Fath. It is narrated that Abu Bakr said to Zaid and Umar bin Al-Khattab: Sit at the door of the mosque, and whoever comes to you with two witnesses for something of the Book of Allah, write it. (2) Third: Everyone who brought something of the Quran was asked to bring two witnesses that this was written in the presence of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. (3) Fourth: Zaid performed the writing of the Quran by matching what was written of the Quran in the time of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, with what the Companions preserved in their chests of the Quran. Zaid said: So I tracked down the Quran collecting it from palm stalks, thin stones, and the chests of men, until I found the end of Surah At-Tawbah with Abu Khuzaima Al-Ansari, I did not find it with anyone else. (4) Meaning he did not find it written except with Abu Khuzaima, otherwise Zaid and other Companions memorized these verses, but he wanted the verses to be memorized AND written, for increased authentication and precaution. Al-Hafiz Ibn Hajar said: The benefit of tracking down was exaggeration in seeking verification and standing upon the exact thing written in the presence of the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace. (5) Fifth: The beginning of the task of collecting the Quran was after the Battle of Yamama at the end of year 11 AH, and it ended before the death of Abu Bakr in the middle of year 13 AH. Sixth: After writing the Quran and collecting it, it was handed to Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq and remained with him until his death, then remained with Umar until he was martyred at the hands of Abu Lu'lu'ah the Magian, so it remained with Mother of Believers Hafsa bint Umar, may Allah be pleased with them both. Then Uthman requested it to copy copies for the regions from it and returned it to Hafsa.

text: Bakr - may Allah be pleased with him - the Second Compilation - on consistent pieces equal in size, arranged by verses and Surahs, in a documental manner for which human history has known no equal in terms of control and mastery. Ali bin Abi Talib - may Allah be pleased with him - says: The person with the greatest reward regarding the Mushaf is Abu Bakr; may Allah have mercy on Abu Bakr, he was the first to collect the Book of Allah. (1) Chapter Four: The date and time of this compilation and its most prominent results. It contains two sections: Section One: The most prominent results of Abu Bakr's compilation - may Allah be pleased with him. Undoubtedly, the motive for this compilation was fear of the loss of its carriers following the killing of seventy reciters on the Day of Yamama. Its collection began after that battle, meaning approximately at the end of the eleventh year of Hijra, and the task of collection ended before the death of Abu Bakr - may Allah be pleased with him - in the middle of the thirteenth year of Hijra. The period of his caliphate - may Allah be pleased with him - was from: the twelfth of Rabi' al-Awwal year 11 AH to the twenty-second of Jumada al-Akhirah year 13 AH. It is said the compilation period took fifteen months, and other things are said. In reality, this is approximate speech and cannot be asserted with certainty due to lack of finding anything fixed and documented confirming that duration precisely. And Allah knows best. In concluding the discussion on this compilation, we discuss two important issues: First: This compilation was completed by consensus of the noble Companions - may Allah be pleased with them all. Second: With its collection, a kind of reassurance was achieved against the fear of its loss or escaping of anything from its complete documentation. Third: This compilation was done according to the most reliable methods of collection and precaution for the Book of Allah Almighty. It was collected by two methods of preservation - chest (memory) and line (writing) - then everything collected was recorded in one place based on that. Nothing was accepted for recording in it except what the Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - agreed was Quran and its narration was Mutawatir as well. Fourth: This compilation became the single trusted and recorded copy upon which all Companions - may Allah be pleased with them all - agreed regarding its correctness and the safety of everything in it from addition and subtraction. Fifth: By the consensus of the Companions - may Allah be pleased with them - and their agreement on this compilation, every suspicion was removed, especially suspicions of innovation and introducing into religion. Finally: It has become clear to us in the folds of the research: "That Abu Bakr Al-Siddiq's collection of the Quran was due to his fear that part of the Quran would go with the passing of its carriers; because it was not collected in one place. So he collected it in sheets arranged by verses of its Surahs according to what the Prophet, may Allah bless him and grant him peace, instructed them." (2) With this, the difference between the compilation in its two eras: First and Second, becomes clear.

text: Section Two: The first to name the Quran "Al-Mushaf". Al-Zarkashi - may Allah have mercy on him - said in Al-Burhan: "Al-Muzaffari (d. 642 AH) mentioned in his history: When Abu Bakr collected the Quran, he said: Name it. Some said: Name it Gospel (*Injil*). They disliked it. Some said: Name it Scroll (*Sifr*). They disliked it from the Jews. Ibn Masud said: I saw a book belonging to the Abyssinians which they call the Mushaf, so name it that." (1) In truth, a narration like this is not relied upon because it has no chain to rely on, and it was narrated as Mursal (disconnected) without attribution or chain. It contradicts what is established from the hadith of Anas - may Allah be pleased with him - in Al-Bukhari where he mentioned the sheets (*Suhuf*) in his saying: So Uthman sent to Hafsa: Send us the sheets (*Suhuf*) so we may copy them into the volumes (*Masahif*)... until he said: So they did so until when they had copied the sheets into the volumes, Uthman returned the sheets to Hafsa, and sent to every region a volume from what they had copied, and ordered that everything else of the Quran in every sheet or volume be burned. (2). There are other traditions like what Al-Muzaffari mentioned - as well - but they do not rise to the degree of confirmation and certainty. "Al-Mushaf" is an Arabic word: The word *Sahifah* is a noun: plural *Sahifat*, *Saha'if*, *Sihaf*, and *Suhuf*. The plural is *Sahif*. *Sahifah* is what is written in of paper and the like, and it applies to what is written in it. Plural: *Suhuf*. (3) So the word is pure Arabic. Even assuming the correctness of what was attributed regarding the Abyssinians using it - as well - perhaps it is among the shared vocabulary between the two languages. Voweling of the word "Mushaf" and clarifying its meaning in language: The famous origin in voweling the word is: "Mushaf" with Damma on Mim, and "Mishaf" with Kasra is permissible, which is the dialect of Tamim. *Mushaf*: A name for every collection of written sheets joined between two covers. It came in (Al-Lisan) from Al-Azhari - may Allah have mercy on him: "The Mushaf was named Mushaf because it was *Ushifa*, meaning made a collector of written sheets between two covers." (4) The implication of Al-Fayruzabadi's speech - may Allah have mercy on him - is: That *Mushaf* (with Damma): Is a passive participle from *Ashafahu* meaning he collected it. *Mashaf* (with Fatha): Place of sheets, meaning: gathering place of sheets. *Mishaf* (with Kasra): Tool collecting sheets. (5) Al-Shihab Al-Khafaji (1069 AH) said: "Mushaf with Damma on Mim and Kasra, and Triplication (Fatha too) was narrated in it; it is the gathering of sheets from *Ashafa* meaning collected, and it is specific to the Quran." (6) Al-Farra' (d. 207 AH) said: "The Arabs found Damma heavy in letters so they broke their Mim (Kasra), and their origin is Damma. From that is *Mushaf*, *Mukhda'*, *Mutraf*, *Mighzal*, and *Mujsad*; because in meaning they are taken from *Ashafa* (sheets were collected in it)..."
